newsitem.title: UK: IPE gas oil targets $200 as backwardation widens.
newsitem.headline: IPE gas oil targets $200 as backwardation widens.

text.p: IPE September gas oil's ascent toward $200 a tonne on Thursday reflects a widening in the futures market's backwardation that is discouraging inventory building ahead of the key fourth quarter demand period.

As a result, outright gas oil futures and gas oil spreads versus the back months and crude are expected to stay firm as the summer draws to a close, with lean distillate supplies in the United States offering little relief, analysts said.

But they cautioned that, for the near-term, the strength may be exaggerated due to the NYMEX Sept products expiries on Friday, the U.S. Labor Day holiday weekend, and talk that one player was a large buyer of Sept gas oil this morning.

"Because of the backwardation there is no incentive to restock," said Geoff Pyne, oil economist at UBS in London. "Also I think storage companies are looking for contango this time of year going into winter and they're not seeing it."

"I think gas oil is the single strongest fundamental support in the oil market and that will continue lending support to crude in September," he added. "Consumer inventories are low so there is quite a lot of potential demand to come in September."
European middle distillate stocks as of July were 282.53 million barrels, down from 293.02 million a year ago, according to Euroilstock Foundation.
Sept gas oil was up $5.75 at $197.50 a tonne in afternoon trade after reaching $198.50, a contract high and the strongest level for the spot month since $200 on April 9.
The year's high was registered on March 27 at $200.50, which in turn was the highest since $223 in November 1991 during the Gulf War.

The backwardation, or front-month premium over the second month, for Sept/Oct was trading at 50 cents on August 12 and widened out to $2 on Wednesday. It was trading at about $3.25 Thursday afternoon.
The Oct/Nov backwardation was trading at about $3.50. Sept gas oil expires September 12 while NYMEX Sept heating oil exits on Friday.

"If we see this backwardation holding then we could have problems going into winter because there is less financial incentive to hold inventories," said Leslie Nicholas, analyst at GNI Ltd in London. "That's a potential problem."

"Two hundred dollars could be a target to be attained but gas oil's instrinic fundamentals don't warrant sustained levels above $200 at the moment," he added. "I don't see the market particularly tight in Europe versus in the U.S."

European distillate fundamentals are less bullish than in the U.S., where inventories are 19 million barrels below year-ago levels, but NYMEX heating oil prices could be a leader for the gas oil market, he said.
If prices are in contango, with the front month trading below the second month contract, the cost of carrying the inventory can be offset by not having to buy at a higher price later.
"I don't know how sustainable this whole rally is," said one oil broker.

But he still cited a host of factors underpinning the gas oil market -- Sept holding an uptrend line on the continuation chart that crossed at $188; worries over hurricanes and tropical storms in the Atlantic; and this week's U.S. inventory data.
